qas.question: When did a cappella begin to take hold in the United States?
What was the name of the choir F. Mellus Christiansen used?
How many singers are typically in the choirs?
Who did the St. Olaf Choir influence?
What tradition was started in the western US?
Who spoke against a cappella in 1911?
What was emulated by other conductors across the country?
What do a capella choirs struggle to perfect in a large choral setting?
Who started a prominent choir in 1911?
At what college was F. Melius Christiansen a student?

plausible_answers.text: the local St. John's Lutheran Church

qas.question: What church was Augsburg College connected to?
How many singers are in a cappella?

context: A strong and prominent <b4_0>a cappella<b4_0/> tradition was begun in the midwest part of the United States in <a0_0>1911<a0_0/> by <b5_0><b8_0>F. Melius Christiansen<b8_0/><b5_0/>, a music faculty member at <b9_0>St. Olaf College<b9_0/> in Northfield, Minnesota. <a1_0>The St. Olaf College Choir<a1_0/> was established as an outgrowth of <b10_0>the local St. John's Lutheran Church<b10_0/>, where Christiansen was organist and the choir was composed, at least partially, of students from the nearby St. Olaf campus. <b6_0>The success of the ensemble<b6_0/> was emulated by <a3_0><b11_0>other regional conductors<b11_0/><a3_0/>, and a rich tradition of a cappella choral music was born in the region at colleges like Concordia College (Moorhead, Minnesota), Augustana College (Rock Island, Illinois), Wartburg College (Waverly, Iowa), Luther College (Decorah, Iowa), Gustavus Adolphus College (St. Peter, Minnesota), Augustana College (Sioux Falls, South Dakota), and Augsburg College (Minneapolis, Minnesota). The choirs typically range from <a2_0><b12_0>40 to 80<b12_0/><a2_0/> singers and are recognized for their efforts to perfect <b7_0>blend, intonation, phrasing and pitch<b7_0/> in a large choral setting.
